title: Gingen an der Fils
text:
Gingen an der Fils is a municipality in the district of <a href="G%C3%B6ppingen%20%28district%29">Göppingen</a> in <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, <a href="Germany">Germany</a>.
Geography.
The municipality ("<a href="Municipalities%20of%20Germany">Gemeinde</a>") of Gingen an der Fils is found in <a href="G%C3%B6ppingen%20%28district%29">the district</a> of <a href="G%C3%B6ppingen">Göppingen</a>, in <a href="Baden-W%C3%BCrttemberg">Baden-Württemberg</a>, one of the <a href="States%20of%20Germany">16 States</a> of the <a href="Federal%20Republic%20of%20Germany">Federal Republic of Germany</a>. Gingen is physically located in the valley of the <a href="Fils%20%28river%29">Fils</a>, up to the hills of the , in the of the <a href="Swabian%20Jura">Swabian Jura</a>. Elevation above sea level in the municipal area ranges from a high of <a href="Normalnull">Normalnull</a> (NN) to a low of NN.
Gingen an der Fils includes the hamlet of Grünenberg as well as the <a href="ghost%20town">ghost town</a> Marrbach.
Geological demographics.
Source:
History.
Some time between 1382 and 1396, Gingen was sold by the <a href="House%20of%20Helfenstein">County of Helfenstein</a> to the <a href="Free%20Imperial%20City">Free Imperial City</a> of <a href="Ulm">Ulm</a>, whose bailiff resided in the town until 1750. Gingen became a possession of the <a href="Electorate%20of%20Bavaria">Electorate of Bavaria</a> in 1802, but was ceded in 1810 to the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20W%C3%BCrttemberg">Kingdom of Württemberg</a>. Gingen was assigned to . In 1845, the town was connected to the growing network of railways in Europe by the construction of the <a href="Fils%20Valley%20Railway">Fils Valley Railway</a>. Gingen was reassigned in 1938 to the district of Göppingen and entered a period of <a href="urban%20growth">urban growth</a> after <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, nearly doubling in physical size. Since the turn of the millennium, urban sprawl has primarily been to Gingen's west.
Politics.
Gingen has one borough ("Ortsteil"), Gingen an der Fils, and three villages: Grünenberg, Hämmelplatz, and Marren. The <a href="abandoned%20villages">abandoned villages</a> of Ferrenbronn, Liebenweiler, Marchbach, and Weschenbeuren are also found in the municipal area.
Council.
The municipal council in Gingen has 14 members. The municipal elections on May 26, 2019 led to the most recent council members.
Mayors.
Source:
Insignia.
Coat of arms.
Gingen an der Fils's <a href="coat%20of%20arms">coat of arms</a> displays a <a href="Field%20%28heraldry%29">field</a> of <a href="Argent">white</a> crossed by a <a href="bend%20sinister">bend sinister</a>, in <a href="Azure%20%28heraldry%29">blue</a>, with a <a href="Gules">red</a> in the top left corner of the <a href="blazon">blazon</a>. This pattern was devised and adopted for use by the municipal council in 1922 and refers to the river Fils and to a local church where, supposedly, the oldest surviving written document in Germany was written. The <a href="Federal%20Ministry%20of%20the%20Interior%2C%20Building%20and%20Community">Federal Ministry of the Interior</a> approved the coat of arms and issued a corresponding municipal flag on 5 December 1958.
Transportation.
Gingen is connected to <a href="Driving%20in%20Germany">Germany's network of roadways</a> by <a href="Bundesstra%C3%9Fe%2010">Bundesstraße 10</a> and to its system of railways by the <a href="Fils%20Valley%20Railway">Fils Valley Railway</a>. Local public transportation is provided by the .
